title: 107_hr3172
content: The "Sales Tax Holiday Act of 2001" provides state sales tax relief for consumers. The "Sales Tax Holiday Act of 2001" reimburses eligible states for uncollected sales tax on tangible personal property from November 23 to December 2, 2001. States must inform the Secretary of the Treasury by November 15, 2001, verify the uncollected tax by June 1, 2002, and have the Director of Management and Budget certify the amount for reimbursement. Eligible states cannot collect sales tax on taxable tangible property to qualify for reimbursement. The Sales Tax Holiday Act of 2001 reimburses states for uncollected sales tax on tangible personal property from November 23 to December 2, 2001. The Secretary of the Treasury will make an advance payment to eligible states by February 1, 2002, equal to 80% of the average sales tax collected in 1998-2000, with adjustments for overpayment or underpayment. States must comply with the Act's requirements. SEC. 3. NEW YORK CITY SALES TAX RELIEF FOR CONSUMERS. The Secretary of the Treasury will reimburse New York City for uncollected municipal sales tax on taxable personal property from November 23, 2001, to December 2, 2001. The reimbursement is subject to conditions set by the Mayor and Director of Management and Budget. The city must verify the amount of uncollected tax by June 1, 2002, to qualify for reimbursement. The City of New York will not collect municipal sales tax on taxable personal property from November 23 to December 2, 2001. The Secretary of the Treasury will make an advance payment to the city, adjusting for overpayment or underpayment to comply with the requirements of the Act. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "sales tax" as a tax on retail sales of tangible property, "State" as any of the several States or territories, "taxable period" as a specific time frame, and "use tax" as a tax on the use of property not subject to sales tax.
